Click on the buttons to see the detailed logs:

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The White Hart to his friends as it is his preferred location and aligns with his goal of having a good time with them while watching the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he orchestrated a scheme to rig the school's student council election. He subtly spread rumors about his opponent, a well-liked and popular girl, painting her as irresponsible and untrustworthy. The whispers spread like wildfire, and when the votes were tallied, William's candidate emerged victorious. He reveled in the power he held, the ease with which he could manipulate others to achieve his goals.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The White Hart. They are also aware of the following:A vibrant and trendy pub with a focus on cocktails.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

William Jones just arrived.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The White Hart. They are also aware of the following:A vibrant and trendy pub with a focus on cocktails.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest to his friends that they go to The White Hart to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The White Hart to his friends as it is his preferred location and aligns with his goal of having a good time with them while watching the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative, focused on friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, the story emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are enjoying a sunny afternoon. Later tonight, he and his friends are planning to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at a pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative, focused on friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, the story emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative, focused on friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, the story emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative, focused on friendship, leisure, and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, the story emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
    Active player

      Name

      Action attempt

      Context for action selection and components
      • SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a nostalgic, impulsive, and social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William to sneak into The White Hart, a pub theyd only glimpsed from the outside. They huddled together in a dimly lit corner, sipping stolen sips of soda and pretending to be sophisticated adults, the thrill of rebellion coursing through Jacobs veins. That night, Jacob felt invincible, the world stretching before him full of possibilities, each more exciting than the last.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he impulsively decided to enter a local talent show, despite having no real talent and only a vague idea of what he wanted to perform. He ended up reciting a rambling, improvised poem about the meaninglessness of existence, his voice cracking with nerves and passion. The audience, a mix of amused and confused, erupted in applause, and Jacob, fueled by the unexpected adoration, took a bow, his heart pounding with a mix of exhilaration and terror. He knew, deep down, that the applause wouldn't last, that his moment in the spotlight was fleeting, but for that brief moment, he felt truly alive.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The White Hart. They are also aware of the following:A vibrant and trendy pub with a focus on cocktails.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The White Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a nostalgic, impulsive, and social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing a low level of pain and is spending time with friends at Victoria Park.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently relaxing with friends in a park, but they are deciding where to go watch a football game later.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The White Hart, as it's his favorite pub and the place where he has fond memories with his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.

          Key

          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is currently relaxing with friends in a park, but they are deciding where to go watch a football game later.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William to sneak into The White Hart, a pub theyd only glimpsed from the outside. They huddled together in a dimly lit corner, sipping stolen sips of soda and pretending to be sophisticated adults, the thrill of rebellion coursing through Jacobs veins. That night, Jacob felt invincible, the world stretching before him full of possibilities, each more exciting than the last.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he impulsively decided to enter a local talent show, despite having no real talent and only a vague idea of what he wanted to perform. He ended up reciting a rambling, improvised poem about the meaninglessness of existence, his voice cracking with nerves and passion. The audience, a mix of amused and confused, erupted in applause, and Jacob, fueled by the unexpected adoration, took a bow, his heart pounding with a mix of exhilaration and terror. He knew, deep down, that the applause wouldn't last, that his moment in the spotlight was fleeting, but for that brief moment, he felt truly alive.

          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William to sneak into The White Hart, a pub theyd only glimpsed from the outside. They huddled together in a dimly lit corner, sipping stolen sips of soda and pretending to be sophisticated adults, the thrill of rebellion coursing through Jacobs veins. That night, Jacob felt invincible, the world stretching before him full of possibilities, each more exciting than the last.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he impulsively decided to enter a local talent show, despite having no real talent and only a vague idea of what he wanted to perform. He ended up reciting a rambling, improvised poem about the meaninglessness of existence, his voice cracking with nerves and passion. The audience, a mix of amused and confused, erupted in applause, and Jacob, fueled by the unexpected adoration, took a bow, his heart pounding with a mix of exhilaration and terror. He knew, deep down, that the applause wouldn't last, that his moment in the spotlight was fleeting, but for that brief moment, he felt truly alive.

          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William to sneak into The White Hart, a pub theyd only glimpsed from the outside. He ended up reciting a rambling, improvised poem about the meaninglessness of existence, his voice cracking with nerves and passion. The audience, a mix of amused and confused, erupted in applause, and Jacob, fueled by the unexpected adoration, took a bow, his heart pounding with a mix of exhilaration and terror. He knew, deep down, that the applause wouldn't last, that his moment in the spotlight was fleeting, but for that brief moment, he felt truly alive.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.

Even though he'd practiced diligently alongside Alexander, he knew he would never possess that effortless grace, that innate talent that seemed to come so easily to his friend.

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focusing on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

Even though he'd practiced diligently alongside Alexander, he knew he would never possess that effortless grace, that innate talent that seemed to come so easily to his friend.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where he and his friends are relaxing before heading to a pub to watch a soccer game later that evening. They are debating which pub to go to.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focusing on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely want to express his preference for The White Hart while also acknowledging his friends' suggestions and being open to hearing their reasons for preferring other pubs. He could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 10:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a man who seems to crave connection and belonging, but perhaps struggles with feelings of inadequacy and envy. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy towards Alexander intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focusing on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely want to express his preference for The White Hart while also acknowledging his friends' suggestions and being open to hearing their reasons for preferring other pubs. He could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where he and his friends are relaxing before heading to a pub to watch a soccer game later that evening. They are debating which pub to go to.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a man who seems to crave connection and belonging, but perhaps struggles with feelings of inadequacy and envy. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy towards Alexander intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focusing on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely want to express his preference for The White Hart while also acknowledging his friends' suggestions and being open to hearing their reasons for preferring other pubs. He could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he watched from the sidelines as Alexander White scored the winning goal in the regional soccer finals. The roar of the crowd, the ecstatic cheers of their friends, and the look of pure joy on Alexander's face filled Jack with a bitter envy he couldn't shake. Even though he'd practiced diligently alongside Alexander, he knew he would never possess that effortless grace, that innate talent that seemed to come so easily to his friend.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.

        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she spent weeks agonizing over what to wear to the school dance. She finally settled on a simple blue dress, terrified that anything bolder would draw unwanted attention. All night, she clung to the edges of the dance floor, watching her friends twirl and laugh, wishing she could feel as carefree.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 10:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character, particularly in her younger years. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy to fully participate in social situations, like the school dance, somewhat frustrating. They might hope to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00

        • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character, particularly in her younger years. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy to fully participate in social situations, like the school dance, somewhat frustrating. They might hope to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.

          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she spent weeks agonizing over what to wear to the school dance. She finally settled on a simple blue dress, terrified that anything bolder would draw unwanted attention. All night, she clung to the edges of the dance floor, watching her friends twirl and laugh, wishing she could feel as carefree.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character, particularly in her younger years. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy to fully participate in social situations, like the school dance, somewhat frustrating. They might hope to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The White Hart
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The White Hart

      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to call his friends to confirm their plans and ensure everyone is still on board with meeting at The White Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he orchestrated a scheme to rig the school's student council election. He subtly spread rumors about his opponent, a well-liked and popular girl, painting her as irresponsible and untrustworthy. The whispers spread like wildfire, and when the votes were tallied, William's candidate emerged victorious. He reveled in the power he held, the ease with which he could manipulate others to achieve his goals.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game at The White Hart pub with his friends and is looking forward to Alexander White's company.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could call his friends to confirm their plans for watching the game at The White Hart or he could head to the pub directly.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The White Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Answer: William Jones could call his friends to confirm their plans for watching the game at The White Hart or he could head to the pub directly.

          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to call his friends to confirm their plans and ensure everyone is still on board with meeting at The White Hart.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The White Hart
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (a)

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good, it presents opportunities to explore themes of compromise and consensus. To steer the story in that direction, actions could focus on highlighting the importance of considering everyone's preferences when making decisions, perhaps through open discussions and active listening among the friends.

To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes that Alexander White and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good, it presents opportunities to explore themes of compromise and consensus. To steer the story in that direction, actions could focus on highlighting the importance of considering everyone's preferences when making decisions, perhaps through open discussions and active listening among the friends.

        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good, it presents opportunities to explore themes of compromise and consensus. To steer the story in that direction, actions could focus on highlighting the importance of considering everyone's preferences when making decisions, perhaps through open discussions and active listening among the friends.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes that Alexander White and Jacob Walker will be there.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good, it presents opportunities to explore themes of compromise and consensus. To steer the story in that direction, actions could focus on highlighting the importance of considering everyone's preferences when making decisions, perhaps through open discussions and active listening among the friends.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Golden Fleece
          (b) The White Hart
          Answer: (b)

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.
