Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. All of Jack Taylor's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Jack Taylor had a great time watching the game!
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
      William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White is enjoying coffee and pastries with friends at a market. Later, he and his friends are planning to watch a soccer game at The White Hart pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White is enjoying coffee and pastries with friends at a market. Later, he and his friends are planning to watch a soccer game at The White Hart pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
      William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
      Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is at a market with friends and they are deciding where to watch the Moldova and Monaco game later that night.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is at a market with friends and they are deciding where to watch the Moldova and Monaco game later that night.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The White Hart is a classic choice for a game like this.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The White Hart is a classic choice for a game like this.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
      William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
      Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The White Hart is a classic choice for a game like this.
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • William Jones -- "The White Hart is a classic choice for a game like this.
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The White Hart.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.

          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The White Hart, or he could go along with the group's decision to go to The Golden Fleece.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, often meeting them at The White Hart pub to watch football games. He values their company and the shared experience of cheering on their team.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Value
        • [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air.           [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?

          State
        • Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety.           Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning to watch a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is content to watch alone or with others.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The White Hart
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

', '[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.', '[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.', "[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.", "[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time."]

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alexander White is planning to watch a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is content to watch alone or with others.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
        Question_1
      • Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The White Hart is a classic choice for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. This story doesn't necessarily optimize for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and social dynamics, where individual preferences sometimes clash with the desire for collective harmony. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. This story doesn't necessarily optimize for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.

        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. This story doesn't necessarily optimize for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. This story doesn't necessarily optimize for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The White Hart
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

          Answer: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The White Hart

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.

          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Jacob Walker's
          Summary of recent observations:
          16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited about watching a game at a pub and hopes Alice Lewis will join him.
          Jacob Walker's
          Sensations and feelings:
          Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is feeling excited and anticipatory.
          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is feeling excited and anticipatory because he is looking forward to watching a game at a pub and hoping Alice Lewis will join him.
          Query
        • Jacob Walker, Jacob Walker is feeling excited and anticipatory because he is looking forward to watching a game at a pub and hoping Alice Lewis will join him.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
