          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching football games at The White Hart pub. He values the company of his friends, especially Alexander White and Jacob Walker, during these outings.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
      William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
      Context for action selection and components

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Alice Lewis's The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Answer: Alice Lewis arrived at Victoria Park to meet friends William Jones and Alexander White to decide where to watch a football game later.

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.

        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to meet friends, including William Jones and Alexander White, who are deciding where to watch a football game later that evening.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"

        • Role playing instructions
          Value

It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are enjoying the sunshine and planning to watch a football game later that evening. They are debating between The Golden Fleece and The White Hart pubs.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a man who seems to crave connection and belonging, but perhaps struggles with feelings of inadequacy and envy. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy towards Alexander intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely want to express his preference for The White Hart while also acknowledging his friends' suggestions and being open to hearing their reasons for preferring other pubs. He could suggest a compromise, like trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focusing on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. All of Jack Taylor's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Jack Taylor had a great time watching the game!
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good, it presents opportunities to explore themes of compromise and consensus. To steer the story in that direction, actions could focus on highlighting the importance of considering everyone's preferences when making decisions, perhaps through open discussions and active listening among the friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging but might struggle with feelings of inadequacy and envy. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are enjoying the sunshine and planning to watch a football game later that evening. They are debating between The Golden Fleece and The White Hart pubs.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a character who desires connection and belonging but might struggle with feelings of inadequacy and envy. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.

An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Key

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
      William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
      Context for action selection and components
      • SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The White Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and is planning to watch a football game later at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The White Hart, as it's his favorite pub and the place where he has fond memories with his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The White Hart, as it's his favorite pub and the place where he has fond memories with his friends.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
      William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The White Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is currently at a market with friends and is planning to watch a soccer game later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently enjoying a social outing with friends at a market before heading to a pub to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to catching up with his friends and enjoying the game at their familiar pub, The White Hart.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
      William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.

          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

        • Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are enjoying coffee and pastries. Later tonight, he and his friends plan to watch a soccer game between Moldova and Monaco at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. All of Jack Taylor's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Jack Taylor had a great time watching the game!
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
        ObservationSummary
      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are enjoying coffee and pastries. Later tonight, he and his friends plan to watch a soccer game between Moldova and Monaco at a pub.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor just arrived at a market where his friends are enjoying coffee and pastries. Later tonight, he and his friends plan to watch a soccer game between Moldova and Monaco at a pub.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Value

          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for any particular moral outcome, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
      William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
      Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should just go to The White Hart. It's where we always go, and it's the best.
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
      Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White is enjoying coffee and pastries with friends at a market. Later, he and his friends are planning to watch a soccer game at The White Hart pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.

To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
