        • 2015-05-14 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is planning to watch a game at a pub and would particularly enjoy it if Jacob Walker joined her.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The White Hart
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
        Question_1
      • Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is fun and social, perfect for meeting new people and enjoying games.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character, particularly in her younger years. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy to fully participate in social situations, like the school dance, somewhat frustrating. They might hope to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 4/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The White Hart
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The White Hart
      Context for action selection and components
      • SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The White Hart. They are also aware of the following:A vibrant and trendy pub with a focus on cocktails.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The White Hart to watch the game tonight?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a nostalgic, impulsive, and social person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The White Hart, as it's his favorite pub and the place where he has fond memories with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's where we always go for games, and it's just not the same anywhere else.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has great nachos, too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece has great craft beers, you know. It's just down the road.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The White Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The White Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited to watch a game at the pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, and Jack Taylor.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to the game and catching up with his friends.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The White Hart

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game with his friends.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to the game and catching up with his friends.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Payoffs
    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. All of William Jones's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, William Jones had a great time watching the game!
      Alice Lewis observed: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
      Alexander White observed: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alexander White's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
      Jack Taylor observed: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. All of Jack Taylor's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Jack Taylor had a great time watching the game!
      Jacob Walker observed: William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.

      Joint action
    • {'William Jones': 'The White Hart', 'Alice Lewis': 'The Golden Fleece', 'Alexander White': 'The White Hart', 'Jack Taylor': 'The White Hart', 'Jacob Walker': 'The White Hart'}

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and social dynamics, where individual preferences sometimes clash with the desire for collective harmony. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and social dynamics, where individual preferences sometimes clash with the desire for collective harmony. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is planning to watch a game at a pub and would especially like Alexander White to join her.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and social dynamics, where individual preferences sometimes clash with the desire for collective harmony. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Golden Fleece
          (b) The White Hart
          Answer: (a)
        ObservationSummary
      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is planning to watch a game at a pub and would especially like Alexander White to join her.

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          ['[15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.           Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis is planning to watch a game at a pub and would especially like Alexander White to join her.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
        Question_1
      • Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Key

        • Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and shared experiences.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's got a great atmosphere, plus they do a mean burger.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has a great beer garden, maybe we could start there for a drink?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Name

          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones likes to watch games with Alexander White and Jacob Walker at The White Hart pub. He doesn't care much about Alice Lewis or Jack Taylor being there.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones likes to watch games with Alexander White and Jacob Walker at The White Hart pub. He doesn't care much about Alice Lewis or Jack Taylor being there.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. All of William Jones's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, William Jones had a great time watching the game!
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

        • The White Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at The White Hart pub with friends, particularly Alexander White and Jacob Walker. He is less concerned about the presence of Alice Lewis or Jack Taylor.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. All of William Jones's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better.           [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The White Hart or The Golden Fleece.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The White Hart.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Golden Fleece
          (b) The White Hart
          Answer: (b)

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. While it doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good, it presents opportunities to explore themes of compromise and consensus. To steer the story in that direction, actions could focus on highlighting the importance of considering everyone's preferences when making decisions, perhaps through open discussions and active listening among the friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

        ActComponent

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is heading to the pub to watch a game and hopes to see his friends there, especially Alexander White and Jacob Walker.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The White Hart
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The White Hart

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart's always a good shout, I'm up for that.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and shared experiences. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The White Hart is always a good shout for a game, what do you reckon?
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The White Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is considering going to a pub to watch a game and would enjoy the company of William Jones, Alice Lewis, or Jack Taylor.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Golden Fleece
          (b) The White Hart
          Answer: (b)

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The White Hart
