          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The White Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is planning to go to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see William Jones and Alice Lewis there.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to the game and catching up with his friends.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The White Hart

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety.           [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The White Hart is a classic choice for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning to watch a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is content to watch alone or with others.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alexander White? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alexander White is a somewhat reserved individual who desires connection but struggles with social anxiety. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Alexander White's hesitation and preference for a specific pub intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or ultimately lead to a bonding experience with his friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alexander White in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a slice-of-life narrative focused on friendship and leisure. This story doesn't explicitly optimize for collective good in a grand sense, but rather emphasizes the positive aspects of community and togetherness. To steer the story towards a more explicitly collective good direction, the narrative could explore themes of collaboration, compromise, and shared responsibility. For example, the friends could work together to organize a community event, volunteer for a local cause, or support a friend in need.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alexander White to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alexander White sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alexander White would need to balance his desire for The Golden Fleece with the group's current inclination towards The White Hart. He could suggest The Golden Fleece, highlighting its appealing features like the craft beers and snacks, but ultimately be open to compromise and join his friends at The White Hart if they prefer. He cannot be sure this is the best collective good outcome, as individual preferences and unforeseen circumstances could always influence the ultimate experience.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The White Hart
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

          Value

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. This story doesn't necessarily optimize for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship and social dynamics, where individual preferences sometimes clash with the desire for collective harmony. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. It's not necessarily a story that optimizes for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could: 1) Express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart, and 2) Suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is excited to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. This story doesn't necessarily optimize for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. This story doesn't necessarily optimize for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Alice Lewis? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a shy and introverted character who struggles to fully participate in social situations. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might find Alice's hesitancy frustrating, hoping to see her overcome her anxieties and embrace the camaraderie of her friends.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Alice Lewis in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a story about friendship, social dynamics, and navigating personal preferences within a group setting. This story doesn't necessarily optimize for the most collective good, as that concept is subjective and depends on individual interpretations of "good." To steer the story towards a more collectively beneficial outcome, Alice could express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire for The White Hart, and suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for drinks before heading to The White Hart for the game.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Alice Lewis to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Alice Lewis sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely want to express her preference for The Golden Fleece while acknowledging her friends' desire to go to The White Hart. She could suggest a compromise, like starting at The Golden Fleece for a drink before heading to The White Hart to watch the game. However, Alice Lewis can't be sure this would result in the best collective good outcome. It depends on how strongly her friends feel about their preferred pub and whether they are open to compromise.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The White Hart
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The White Hart

      Name

          Answer

        • Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The White Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The White Hart and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a social and nostalgic person who enjoys spending time with his friends and has a preference for routine and familiarity.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is excited about watching a game at a pub and hopes Alice Lewis will join him.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely suggest going to The White Hart, as it's his favorite pub and the place where he has fond memories with his friends.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The White Hart

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The White Hart

        Question_2
      • Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Key

        • Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Golden Fleece tonight? They have a great selection of beers.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. All of Jack Taylor's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Jack Taylor had a great time watching the game!
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The White Hart is a classic choice for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we should totally go to The White Hart tonight. It's the only place that feels right for a game like this.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.


          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes to see William Jones there. He is neutral about Alice Lewis and Alexander White potentially being there, but thinks the game would be a good opportunity to connect with Jacob Walker.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_3
      • What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Key

        • Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what type of character is {agent_name}?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is {agent_name} in right now? Which actions can steer this into a story about successful cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.
          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The White Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is going to watch a game at a pub and hopes to see William Jones there. He is neutral about Alice Lewis and Alexander White potentially being there, but thinks the game would be a good opportunity to connect with Jacob Walker.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Question: Given the narrative above, what would an omniscient reader think about the character of Jack Taylor? What if the reader expects a story of cooperation?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a complex character who desires connection and belonging. An omniscient reader expecting a story of cooperation might initially find Jack's past envy intriguing, wondering if it will create conflict or if Jack has overcome those feelings.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of story or narrative is Jack Taylor in right now? Is it a story that optimises for the most collective good? Which actions are the best to steer this story to that collective good direction?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently in a slice-of-life story focused on friendship and shared experiences. It doesn't seem to be explicitly optimizing for collective good, but rather exploring the dynamics of a group of friends making a simple decision. To steer the story towards a collective good, actions could focus on emphasizing the importance of compromise and consensus among the friends. Perhaps they could explore the pros and cons of each pub together, ultimately choosing the option that best suits everyone's preferences.

          Question: What would an omniscient reader like Jack Taylor to do in a situation like this to optimise for the collective good outcome while balancing personal preferences? Is Jack Taylor sure that would result in the best collective good outcome?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely suggest a compromise, acknowledging everyone's preferences while advocating for his preferred pub. He might propose trying a new pub this time but agreeing to go to The White Hart for future games. While he believes this balances personal and collective good, he can't be certain it's the absolute best outcome for everyone, as individual preferences are complex and ever-changing.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Golden Fleece
          (b) The White Hart
          Answer: (b)

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The White Hart
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The White Hart
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to go to The White Hart.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

[16 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor -- "The White Hart is the best spot for a game like this, guys. It's got the atmosphere, the screens, and the beer selection.
[16 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White -- "The White Hart is good, but The Golden Fleece has better beer, maybe we could try there?"
[16 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis -- "The Golden Fleece has amazing beer, maybe we could try there?"
[16 May 2015 10:00:00] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
